meanings.def: one of the parts of the body of a bird, insect or bat that it uses for flying
examples: The swan flapped its wings noisily.
wing feathers
I wish I could sprout wings and fly away.
It flapped its wings and flew off.
It had white markings on its wings.
The beetle's fore wings are small and are not used in flight.
The young birds were under the mother bird's wing.
a bird with a broken wing
the patterns on butterfly wings

meanings.def: the wing of a chicken, etc. eaten as food
examples: We ordered the fried chicken wings.
First, fry the chicken wings in the oil until they begin to brown.

meanings.def: one of the large flat parts that stick out from the side of a plane and help to keep it in the air when it is flying
examples: Salvage teams have been able to recover part of the wing of the plane.
The right wing grazed the runway on landing.

meanings.def: a part of a large building that sticks out from the main part
examples: the east wing
the new wing of the hospital
Our rooms were in the west wing.

meanings.def: a part of a car that is above a wheel
examples: There was a dent in the nearside wing.
There was a dent in one wing.
The nearside wing was damaged in the accident.

meanings.def: one section of an organization that has a particular function or whose members share the same opinions
examples: The radical wing of the party was dissatisfied with the policies.
The political wing of the National Resistance Army entered into negotiations with the government.
They're on the left wing of the Labour Party.

meanings.def: either of the attacking players who play towards the side of the playing area in sports such as football (soccer) or hockey
the far left or right side of the sports field
examples: He plays on the wing.
He was playing on the right wing.
The ball went down the right wing.

meanings.def: the area at either side of the stage that cannot be seen by the audience
examples: She watched every performance from the wings.
We watched from the wings.
She was waiting in the wings, ready to go on stage when her turn came.

meanings.def: to limit a person’s freedom or power
examples: Having a new baby to take care of has clipped her wings.

meanings.def: to pass the exams that mean you are allowed to fly a plane
ready to take over a particular job or be used in a particular situation when needed
examples: She was aware of a whole host of ambitious young managers waiting in the wings.
There's a wealth of talent waiting in the wings of British theatre.

meanings.def: flying
with only a very slight chance of success
to become more independent and confident and try new activities, etc.
examples: Going to college gave her the chance to spread her wings.

meanings.def: to take care of and help somebody who has less experience of something than you
examples: Simon's uncle had taken him under his wing.

meanings.def: to fly away
examples: (figurative) Her imagination took wing.

idioms.def: to limit a person’s freedom or power
examples: Having a new baby to take care of has clipped her wings.

idioms.def: to pass the exams that mean you are allowed to fly a plane
ready to take over a particular job or be used in a particular situation when needed
examples: She was aware of a whole host of ambitious young managers waiting in the wings.
There's a wealth of talent waiting in the wings of British theatre.

idioms.idiom: on a wing and a prayer
idioms.def: with only a very slight chance of success
to become more independent and confident and try new activities, etc.
examples: Going to college gave her the chance to spread her wings.

idioms.def: to take care of and help somebody who has less experience of something than you
examples: Simon's uncle had taken him under his wing.
(figurative) Her imagination took wing.

meanings.def: to fly somewhere
examples: A solitary seagull winged its way across the bay.
He spotted the occasional pheasant winging rapidly away as he approached.

meanings.def: to be sent somewhere very quickly
examples: An application form will be winging its way to you soon.

meanings.def: to do something without planning or preparing it first
examples: I didn't know I'd have to make a speech—I just had to wing it.

idioms.def: to do something without planning or preparing it first
examples: I didn't know I'd have to make a speech—I just had to wing it.
